title: Anthrax in the Cattle-Keeping Corridor of Uganda: A One Health Case Study

items.prompt: Would you call this an outbreak? Why or why not?

facilitator_pre_prompts: How do you define a disease cluster?
How do you define an outbreak?

reference_definitions.cluster: Aggregation of cases in a defined area during a defined time period (without reference to whether the number of cases is more than expected).
reference_definitions.outbreak: Occurrence of more cases of a disease than expected in a defined area or among a specific group of people over a defined time period.

instructor_mode.model_answer: The seven patients clearly represent a cluster with similar symptoms and a common exposure. However, we can’t conclude that this is an outbreak, as there is not yet a confirmed diagnosis or other evidence that all patients are suffering from the same illness, nor a complete picture in terms of person, place and time. However, even though an outbreak cannot be confirmed, further investigation seems warranted.

items.prompt: Keeping in mind that all seven index cases were involved in butchering or eating a cow, which government agencies might be interested in participating in the investigation? What types of staff might be part of a field investigation team?

instructor_mode.reframe_option: If this cluster occurred in our country, which of our government agencies would be (or should be) interested?
model_answer: Ministry of Health: epidemiologist, laboratory technician, medical officer (clinician), health promotion/health education officer
Ministry of Agriculture, Animal Industry and Fisheries: veterinary officer/veterinary epidemiologist
Wildlife Authority: environmental health officer
Ministry of Water and Environment: environmental health officer
Local government: District Administrator
Other possible roles: translators, drivers, IT/computer/data entry staff

items.prompt: What was the likely source of infection for the human cases?

instructor_mode.group_activity: Direct participants to work in groups of 3; have half present for 3a.
instructor_mode.model_answer: Cutaneous anthrax is associated with skin contact with material contaminated with anthrax spores. In this case, handling raw or inadequately cooked meat from the infected cow is the likely cause.
discussion_points: People ate the meat; consider gastrointestinal anthrax cases may have occurred or may occur.
Pulmonary (inhalational) anthrax cases are also possible depending on exposures.
Direct human-to-human spread of anthrax is extremely rare.

items.prompt: What was the likely source of infection for the cow?

instructor_mode.group_activity: Direct participants to work in groups of 3; have remaining groups present for 3b.
instructor_mode.model_answer: Livestock often become infected by ingestion of anthrax spores from the soil when grazing.
instructor_mode.important_note: Direct animal-to-animal or human-to-human spread of anthrax is extremely rare.

items.prompt: Which step is missing?

instructor_mode.model_answer: The missing step is Develop Hypotheses (Step 7). Epidemiologists typically start thinking about possible causes early—often during the first phone call.

optional_prompts.prompt: In the context of an outbreak investigation, what is a hypothesis?
optional_prompts.suggested_answer: An informed guess about the possible cause of disease or mode of transmission.

optional_prompts.prompt: How do epidemiologists develop hypotheses for an outbreak?
suggested_answer: Subject matter knowledge (known sources, vehicles, transmission modes)
Review descriptive epidemiology (what explains most cases?)
Look at outliers (unique cases with limited overlapping exposures)
Talk to case-patients (what do they think caused illness?)
Talk to local health officials (what do they think caused the outbreak?)

items.prompt: From a public health perspective, which steps might be approached differently in a zoonotic disease investigation?

model_answer: Step 1: Broader team should include veterinarians and environmental health officers (depending on disease).
Step 4: Case definition may need to include both human and animal case definitions.
Step 5: Case finding may include identifying affected humans and affected animals.
Step 10: Explanation should reconcile evidence from human and animal investigations.
Step 11: Control measures may differ for animals vs humans (e.g., culling applies to animals, not humans).
Step 12: Surveillance may be needed in animal populations not under routine surveillance.
Step 13: Communication between human and animal investigations is essential for coordination.

items.prompt: How does an outbreak case definition differ from a standard surveillance case definition?

instructor_mode.model_answer: The clinical component may be the same (or not), but an outbreak case definition also includes time and place/person specifications.

items.prompt: What are some ways you might look for additional cases (active case finding) among humans?

instructor_mode.facilitation_format: Round-robin: ask each participant to offer one strategy; allow 'Pass'.
model_answer: Routine surveillance/notification data (may be limited here)
Hospital/in-patient data (record review)
Ask cases about similarly affected family/contacts
Meetings with community leaders
Door-to-door surveillance
Train community health workers to use case definitions
Health promotion teams or local media to educate on prevention/early detection and encourage care seeking
Coordinate with animal health response: follow up humans with contact to identified animal cases

items.prompt: What are the advantages of using a disease-specific case investigation form as part of active case finding?

model_answer: Disease-specific and includes important outbreak context
Standardizes information collected across investigation team members
Improves quality of information obtained from suspected cases

items.prompt: How might information from the animal investigation help the human investigation (and vice versa)?

model_answer: Animal illness/death information can guide where to look for human cases and exposed individuals.
Laboratory confirmation may be faster in one ministry than the other.
Accumulating evidence in either investigation can inform the other when the cause is uncertain.
Interview findings from either team (e.g., beliefs/practices) can inform response activities.
Information sharing helps coordinate and efficiently control diseases threatening human health.

items.prompt: What key information from 22nd April would you add to the Table 2 timeline?

instructor_mode.model_answer: Another cow dies suddenly in the same location as the first cow. Blood samples are collected.

items.prompt: What key information from 23rd–29th April would you add to the Table 2 timeline?

model_answer: 23rd April: Seven cows are found dead on a neighbouring property.
29th April: Another cow is found dead in Kaplobotwo; cattle samples are PCR-positive for anthrax.

items.prompt: What key information from 30th April would you add to the Table 2 timeline?

instructor_mode.model_answer: 30th April: 26 human cases have been identified with onset of symptoms after 11th April.

items.prompt: How would you analyse the data on demographics, clinical symptoms, and exposures?

instructor_mode.facilitation_note: Could begin by asking components of analysis, then small groups for each component.

approach.clinical_features: Frequency distribution (n, %) of type of anthrax (cutaneous, GI, pulmonary).

items.prompt: Add arrows to the epidemic curve to indicate the first three events from the Table 2 timeline.

model_answer: 11th April: Dead cow butchered and eaten.
20th April: First presentations at health centre; notification.
21st April: Investigative team arrives.

items.prompt: Interpret the epidemic curve (Figure 2).

instructor_mode.facilitation_note: Small groups with a timekeeper; reconvene for discussion.
model_answer_points: Describe shape: 8–9 cases on 13th and 14th April, peak on 15th April, sharp decline to 20th April; two late cases on 24th and 25th April.
Interpretation: rapid increase then gradual decline suggests a point source outbreak.
Relate to events/incubation: most cases 2–9 days after exposure; consistent with incubation period (typically 1–7 days).
Outliers: late cases could reflect stored meat eaten later or other exposures; in this investigation they reported eating meat from the index cow and not other dead cows.

items.prompt: Using the line list data in Appendix 3, calculate attack rates and complete Tables 4a and 4b.

instructor_mode.facilitation_note: Small groups; compare results and resolve calculation errors.
instructor_mode.model_answer: The numerator is 48 total cases identified so far. The denominator is 234 total village population. Attack rate (incidence proportion) = (new cases / population at risk) × 100.
notes: Complete attack rates by sex and by age group using the line list.

items.prompt: Calculate attack rates for exposures possibly associated with cutaneous anthrax, based on the data below.

instructor_mode.facilitation_note: Share results and fill in Table 5; resolve errors as a group.
notes: There is no single right answer on whether to include GI-only cases as non-cases or exclude them; results are similar either way.
instructor_mode.model_answer: Participants compute attack rates for each exposure row using (cases / total exposed) × 100.

items.prompt: Why might some livestock owners with sick animals not come forward during an outbreak? How can reporting and compliance be improved?

reasons: Fear livelihood impacts: movement restrictions and intervention costs can cause losses.
Low awareness/understanding of anthrax and need to report.
Extensive management: deaths may not be observed in large low-density herds.
solutions: Government-backed funding and compensation schemes to reduce disincentives.
Build relationships through trusted local representatives.
Local awareness and training programs for best-practice livestock management.

items.prompt: Based on the findings of the outbreak investigation, what short-term and longer-term actions and control measures might you undertake?

instructor_mode.facilitation_note: Split groups: half short/intermediate-term, half longer-term; reconvene to present.

short_term: Case management for infected humans (antibiotics and follow-up care).
Offer prophylactic antibiotics for people exposed to suspected cow cases.
Maintain active case finding in humans for at least two incubation periods (14 days) after last case.
Appropriate disposal of suspected anthrax carcasses and decontamination of death sites.
Ensure compensation is available to reduce disincentives to report.
long_term: Regular coordination meetings between public and animal health investigations.
Community mobilization/sensitization for prevention and control.
Strengthen animal health surveillance in endemic regions.
Vaccinate at-risk livestock to prevent future animal (and human) cases.
Consider movement/trade restrictions where feasible; note practical constraints in communal/nomadic settings.

items.prompt: What are some possible cultural and contextual challenges associated with the proposed control measures, and other factors that are important to consider?

model_answer: Cultural perceptions/understanding of illness/death causes in cattle and humans
Community cooperation and trust in authorities
Access to health services and quality of care
Health-seeking behaviors (including preference for traditional healers)
Availability/supply of antimicrobials, vaccines, and decontamination chemicals
Potential health risks from decontamination chemicals
Fear of livelihood implications leading to under-reporting
Cultural practices/beliefs about carcass disposal
Resource constraints for coordinated animal response
Availability of compensation schemes to facilitate compliance
Difficulty applying movement restrictions in communal/nomadic settings
Enforcement/compliance challenges without adequate compensation and resources

items.prompt: Considering a One Health approach to outbreak investigation and disease control, what challenges can limit effective multisectoral collaboration?

facilitation_notes: Final reflective question—lead a group discussion.
Optionally reorient to participants’ own country context.
model_answer: Lack of awareness of counterparts in other disciplines
Lack of routine communication
Delay in establishing collaboration
Gaps in knowledge of transmission/control measures across humans and animals
Lack of guidelines and channels for data/information sharing
Imbalances in funding/resourcing between public health and animal health agencies
